text: Abstract. A shadowable point for a ow is a point where the shadowing
lemma holds for pseudo-orbits passing through it. We prove that this concept
satises the following properties: the set of shadowable points is invariant and a
G set. A ow has the pseudo-orbit tracing property if and only if every point is
shadowable. The chain recurrent and nonwandering sets coincide when every
chain recurrent point is shadowable. The chain recurrent points which are
shadowable are exactly those that can be are approximated by periodic points
when the ow is expansive. We study the relations between shadowable points
of a homeomorphism and the shadowable points of its suspension ow. We
characterize the set of forward shadowable points for transitive ows and chain
transitive ows. We prove that the geometric Lorenz attractor does not have
shadowable points. We show that in the presence of shadowable points chain
transitive ows are transitive and that transitivity is a necessary condition
for chain recurrent ows with shadowable points whenever the phase space is
connected. Finally, as an application these results we give concise proofs of
some well known theorems establishing that ows with POTP admitting some
kind of recurrence are minimal. These results extends those presented in [10].
The theory of shadowing plays an important role in the qualitative theory of dy-
namical systems. It has been largely studied by many researchers and is well doc-
umented (see for instance [12]). It refers to the general problem of approximating
orbits obtained in the presence of noise or round-o error (for instance solutions
obtained by numerical computations). There are several ways to dene the shad-
owing property for ows, see for instance [13] and references therein. In essence,
the central idea among the majority of denitions of shadowing for ows is the
following: even if small errors occur at each iteration, one can track the resulting
pseudo-orbit by a true orbit with a time reparametrization.
Recently, in [10] the denition of shadowing for homeomorphisms in a compact
metric space was generalized by splitting the shadowing property into pointwise
shadowings giving rise to the concept of shadowable points, which are points where
the shadowing property holds for pseudo-orbits passing through them. In [7] the
author further extends this notion by introducing the concept of quantitative shad-
owable points for homeomorphism and some important question made in [10] were
answered. In light of these results, it is natural to consider a notion of shadowable
points for ows and expect similar results to the homeomorphism case.
Key words and phrases. Shadowing, shadowable points, Metric space.
Partially supported by CAPES from Brazil.
Partially supported by FONDECYT from Peru (C.G. 2172014).
Hence we introduce the concept of shadowable points for ows and we prove
that this notion satises the following properties: the set of shadowable points is
invariant and a G set. A ow has the pseudo-orbit tracing property if and only
if every point is shadowable. The chain recurrent and nonwandering sets coincide
when every chain recurrent point is shadowable. The chain recurrent points which
are shadowable are exactly those that can be are approximated by periodic points
when the ow is expansive. We study the relations between the set of shadowable
points of a homeomorphism and the sets of shadowable points of its suspension
ow. We characterize the set of forward shadowable points for transitive ows
and chain transitive ows and we prove that the geometric Lorenz attractor does
not have shadowable points. We show that in the presence of shadowable points
chain transitive ows are transitive and that transitivity is a necessary condition for
chain recurrent ows with shadowable points whenever the phase space is connected.

Theorem 2.5. Given a ow  in a compact metric space (X, d), the set of shad-

(a) Sh() is invariant possibly empty and noncompact.

Next, we will study the topological behavior of the shadowable points of X. We
shall use the following standard topological concept. A subset of X is a G set if it
is a countable intersection of open sets of X. In [10], examples of homeomorphisms
where the set of shadowable points is a G sets are given. We prove that this is
always the case in the ow context:
Theorem 2.9. The set of shadowable points of  is a G set of X.
Returning to the case of homeomorphisms, in [7] Kawaguchi proved that the
set of shadowable points of a homeomorphism is a Borel set. But what he proved
indeed is that such a set is a F set of phase space, i.e., a countable intersection
of countable union of closed sets. By making use of Theorem 2.9, we improve
Kawaguchis assertion by proving that the set of shadowable points is a G set of
Corollary 2.10. The set of shadowable points of a homeomorphism f : X  X on
a compact metric space X is a G set of X.

Recall that a transitive ow , see [2], is one for which there exists a point x  X
In [10] the question of whether there exists a transitive homeomorphism with non-
trivial shadowable points set is posed.
In [7] the author answers this question
negatively and completely classies the sets of shadowable points for chain transitive
and transitive homeomorphisms. A well known result in topological dynamics states
that every transitive ow is chain transitive [1]. The following corollary, which is
an immediate consequence of Theorem 2.11, gives a partial negative answer to this
Corollary 2.13. If  is a transitive ow, then Sh+() = X or Sh+() = .
Corollary 2.13 can be used to obtain information about the geometric Lorenz
attractor [9, 15]. In [9], it is proved that if  is the geometric Lorenz attractor,
then it does not have the nite forward POTP provided that its return map f
satises that f (0) 6= 0 or f (1) 6= 1. In this case we have Sh+() 6= X. It follows
that Sh+() = . So we obtain the following result.
Corollary 2.14. The geometric Lorenz attractor does not have shadowable points.
We do not know if Theorem 2.11 if we substitute forward shadowables points for

transitive ow is chain transitive. However, it is well known the reciprocal is not
true [1]. The following theorem states that in the presence of forward shadowable
points the two notions are equivalent.
Theorem 2.15. Let X compact metric space and  be a ow with shadowable
points. Then  is chain transitive if and only if is transitive.

Recall that a ow  is distal if whenever inf tR d(t(x), t(y)) = 0 implies x = y.
Komuro showed that isometric ows with the pseudo orbit tracing property are
minimal ows [8]. Meanwhile Kato proved that equicontinuous ows with the
pseudo orbit tracing property are also minimal ows [6]. Later, He and Wang
proved that distal ows with the pseudo-orbit tracing propery are minimal too
[4]. Finally, Jiehua [5] proved that pointwise recurrent ows with the pseudo-orbit
In light of these results, is natural to ask if we still can conclude minimality if
the pointwise recurrence hypothesis is weakened to suppose the ow to be chain re-
current. The answer is negative as there are nonminimal chain recurrent ows with
the pseudo orbit tracing property, for instance the suspension of the usual linear
anosov map on the torus. However, there are not known examples of nontransitive
chain recurrent ows with the pseudo-orbit tracing property on connected spaces.
We are going to proof that transitivity is a necessary condition is the phase space
is assumed to be connected and we give an example that shows that this is not the
case on nonconnected phase spaces. Indeed, If X is assumed to be connected and
chain recurrent, then  is necessarily chain transitive [1]. The following corollary
Corollary 2.17. Let  be a chain recurrent ow with shadowable points on a
compact connected metric space X. Then  is transitive.
The following example shows that the conclusion of Corollary 2.17 cannot be
guaranteed if we drop the connecteness hypothesis.
Example 2.18. In [11], it is proved that an equicontinuous homeomorphism f on a
compact metric space X has the POTP if and only if X is totally disconected. So if
C is the usual ternary Cantor set in the interval [0, 1], then identity map id : C  C
has the POTP. The suspension ow of this map is then a chain recurrent ow that
has POTP [14]. But this ow is not transitive for its phase space is not connected.
The following results mentioned previously can be obtained as a consequence of
Corollary 2.17, giving thus, a more concise proof of these.
